newsitem.title: CANADA: CWB says it extends grain delivery date to Aug 22.
newsitem.headline: CWB says it extends grain delivery date to Aug 22.

text.p: The Canadian Wheat Board on Thursday said it will accept grain delivered up to August 22 to be priced in the 1996/97 (Aug/July) crop year.
"There's still a lot of grain to be delivered - more than the system can handle from now to the end of July," said Lorne Hehn, chief commissioner of the CWB.
The CWB invoked provisions under the Canadian Wheat Board Act to allow for the deferred deliveries.
Western Canadian grain shipments were severely delayed from January to March when extreme cold, heavy snow and rail equipment failure slowed the movement of commodities.
The CWB incurred more than C$15 million in demurrage fines and said it expected 1.5 million tonnes of grain sales to be deferred into the 1997/98 (Aug/July) crop year.
"Many elevators can still accept deliveries and, where possible, I would advise farmers to deliver before the end of July," Hehn said in a statement.
"In area where deferred delivery permits must be used, farmers should deliver as soon after July 31, 1997 as space allows," Hehn added.

Farmers with malting barley storage and delivery contracts will be granted deferred delivery permits automatically. Grain must be called by August 8, 1997 and deliveries under these contracts must be completed within 21 days of being notified.
The CWB's opening 1997/98 delivery calls to farmers will be delayed to accomodate deferred deliveries.
